# 1. introduction the defence law ( the official gazette no. 73 / 13,! [ 6 _ image _ 0. png ] ( 6 _ image _ 0. png ) 75 / 15, 27 / 16, 110 / 17 and 30 / 18 ) defines strategic defence review ( sdr ) as a fundamental document in the field of defence. the sdr represents a final report of the process of reviewing compatibility of strategic concepts and existing and planned defence capabilities with defence requirements deriving from the realities of strategic and security environment. the strategic defence review is also a source of information on the current state, efforts and intentions in the

field of defence for all citizens of the republic of croatia, governmental bodies, international institutions, media, economy, academic community and ngos. as an expression of a wide spectrum of analyses and discussions conducted within defence sector, the strategic defence review outlines recommendations for undertaking measures that will be further developed in other defence planning documents. this document represents a source of guidelines for activities of all components of the defence sector in the upcoming period. it serves as a basis for developing the upcoming long - term development plan of the croatian armed forces ( ltdp ). the main conclusion of the 2013 strategic defence review was that the republic of croatia would develop armed forces suitable

for challenges of the long - term period ahead of us, capable of carrying out its basic constitutional role of defending the country. at the same time, armed forces will possess adequate! [ 6 _ image _ 1. png ] ( 6 _ image _ 1. png ) level of readiness, training and equipping so that they are able to share the burden in operations with allies, but also being at disposal to population endangered by natural and technical - technological disasters and other crisis situations. these guidelines are still relevant ; however, developments in security environment require review of mechanism of their implementation. therefore, it was concluded that social, economic

, strategic and security changes that have taken place in the period from the enactment of the previous strategic defence review ( 2013 ) and the long - term development plan ( 2014 ) require re - evaluation of the situation. upon implementation of the strategic defence review, the development of a new or revision of the existing long - term development plan is required. 7

# # 2. 1 strategic environment and implications for defence \ assessment of the general security context indicates! [ 10 _ image _ 0. png ] ( 10 _ image _ 0. png ) an increased level of uncertainty both in terms of the source of potential military and non - military threats and to manners in which such threats to national security could occur. external and internal security aspects have been increasingly interlinked and that close connection is one of the main factors taken into consideration when defining priorities of the development of the armed forces and to the defence sector as a whole. even though it can be assumed with reasonable level of probability that the

foreseeable future will not bring forth a serious conventional military threat, rapid and unpredictable development of the geopolitical circumstances does not allow us to exclude it entirely. contemporary threats to national security also include indirect operations, not necessarily with intention of endangering a national territory, but with aim to weaken the sovereignty of the state or to influence the state institutions. development of new technologies and their use for military purposes, strengthening of the influence of nonstate actors in international relations and the so - called hybrid activity – which includes simultaneous conventional, hidden, information, and cyber operations - indicate that future military operations will be more complex and multidim

##ensional. achieving goals in operations will demand strong capability of adjustment to changes in multiple operational! represent a major obstacle to multidimensional threats. accordingly, national security strategy, due to changed and expanded security paradigm, calls for greater synergy of the governmental institutions, private sector and citizens.
